CamberbrickGreen,"2012-01-12T03:18:24.97Z","Four Stud Rescue & Repair","I hope there is a BrickList out there that shows every 'mechanic' set up to date. Mechanics, whether they work in a garage or drive a tow truck seem an essential for Town and City themes that have traffic all over the place. The subtheme 'Maintenance' is generally hard to exhaust.

Minifigures:
  • A common feature of mechanic MFs is blue fatigues or dungarees. He is replete with a spanner and umm...hammer?
column2: I suppose you have to break up car wrecks a bit for towing. His shiny black bonce is the hair stuff of 1980's male MF bowlcut trendiness (MF barbers ideally use a mould rather than scissors).&nbsp
column3:
Breakdown Cover
His tools fit neatly in to those interactive bricks, the six stud rails and four stud bars, in this case a suitable grey metal. The blue truck appears low but four stud capable in its towing capacity and has small but special hub capped wheels -those were a welcome design when new.

Grey chassis complements the blue body work really well and the box design is typical but totally suitable with a very nice grey seat. The roof is hinged naturally with the simple but smashing fat little light brick atop in its transparent yellow.

A good graphic or art designer knows to contrast and complement. The towing brick is a well suited example of this in red but yellow would have been equally complementary. This chunky piece has a lovely grey hook on it and is upon a special hinge brick to let it down low to hook-up and tow. This scores well for action.
column4:
Towed Home
The overall build is a nice break from four stud cars and actually rather good although this remains a basic model compared to many larger sets. The MF man turned out to be an important character in our games for no particular reason. Sometimes a set will stretch to blend with others, make new things and reform.

The Vehicle

This was one of the classic style vehicles of the era but was very well designed. The cab has a proper grey seat, the hook unit can be lowered. It even looks quite good with those side bars and low rear section. The roll-bar behind the cab could double as a barrier too.
column5: The few downsides were the lack of a proper grill, a black 2x1 brick was a cheap option (later I replaced mine with a grill brick) and the fact that the hook didn't really hold onto its towed vehicle unless you were travelling slow and in a straight line.
